title: When will COVID-19 cases caused by the Delta variant (B.1.617.2) exceed 350,000 in the UK?
preds: The latest report confirms an additional 57k cases pushing the total to 382k. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-6-august-2021

I'm expecting it to be case closed this morning at roughly 356-362K, but nothing certain yet
Should hear within an hour or two based on previous reports
FINAL: Results now in, higher than expected at 382,022 (maybe the mega-lab has finally started...)
It is past July 28, so decreasing the relevant probabilities to 0.
As of July 30, there is 324k cases, with a 37k weekly increase. Unless something drastic happens, it will occur in the next two weeks.

As we are at 324k cases as of the last update, all that needs to happen for the 350 000 number to be reached by the 11th of August is for the amount of confirmed or probable cases caused by the Delta variant to average ~2k/day or more for the next 2 weeks. It averaged over 5k a day for the last week.  Well over 95% of Covid cases in the UK are caused by the delta variant at the moment and though the amount of cases is declining, the total amount will certainly stay over 2k/day for the coming weeks (it is at 25 000 right now*). The limiting factor is thus the amount of cases that are genotyped or sequenced each day. In England alone, this number hasn't dropped below 2000/day since the end of May when the total amount of detected cases there was barely above 2000 (see note²).

The last time fewer than 2000 confirmed/probable delta cases on average per day were reported for the whole of the UK was in the 3 June update with data till the 26th of May. In that week, there were fewer than 3000 cases/day on average* and many of those were still caused by the Alpha variant: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-3-june-2021 The only way I see the 350 000 target not being reached by 11 August is if the UK suddenly stops sequencing/genotyping cases or if it stops testing within 1-2 days of this comment. There is no indication that such an outcome is even vaguely probable. (Apologies for the formatting, I'm still learning.) ____________________________________________________
*see https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/cases for the amount of cases, not all cases are genotyped, capacity seems to be ~5-6k/day ² Variants of concern: technical briefing 19 – underlying data, Fig 1 at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/investigation-of-novel-sars-cov-2-variant-variant-of-concern-20201201

The delta case numbers for 7/28 have come out and they total 324,000, a 37,000 increase over the 7/21 delta case numbers. I thought that there would be less than 34,000 new delta cases since that was the increase from 7/14-7/21 and the total covid case numbers from 7/21-7/28 were lower than from 7/14-7/21. So the delta case numbers continue to rise even though the total case numbers have come down.  There are only 16,000 more cases until the delta variant reaches the 350,000 threshold and 14 more days of data before August 12th. Although it appears that the total number of covid cases peaked in the 7/14-7/21 time frame there would need to be a greater than 57% decrease in case numbers for the 350,000 case threshold not to be passed on August 4th: let alone August 11.

Just under 38K cases were sequenced in total for this week: from past weeks it seems this is around the ‘normal’ throughput capacity we can expect before the mega-lab gets up to speed.
Now extremely likely that next week’s result will be 350K+, and certainly by the week after that.
Repeating my rational for today's update, but given that rational, these numbers seem more sensible than the ones below.

Latest data suggests it will happen next week.
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-30-july-2021

Further, despite the reduction in cases, we seem to have seen a rise in confirmed delta cases, so we may now be carrying out more variant tests than before.

324,192 this week with 37,427 sequenced over last 7 days.  Pattern so far means we hit 350k next week. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-30-july-2021
Expecting 29-41K sequenced results this week, but given the surprises so far I won’t be shocked unless it’s under 25K or over 55K...

The latest data that has been released is for 21 July with ~286,000 delta variant cases, an increase in ~34,000 over 14 July. That leaves 64,000 cases until we meet the goal of 350,000 It seems that the pace of covid infections is slowing so I would be surprised if there is another >=34,000 increase in the 28 July data. Even if there is a 34,000 increase on 28 July that leaves 30,000 cases which unless there is a massive deceleration in cases makes it very likely that the ~350,000 case mark will occur in between 29 July and 11 August.

Updating forecast. I was right that there was a big difference between a case number and a registered delta variant. Hence why the question remains live. I was wrong that the vaccine once given to young people would cause cases to plummet, as they rose quite quickly for longer than I forecast. My original forecast wasn't expecting it to be this close. Basically I overestimated the vaccine effect. But, case numbers are now falling, partly because of the (still weaker than expected) vaccine effect, and mostly because of school holidays, which are not going away before the end of this forecast. Latest figures say week on week falls of 21%.  So given case numbers are 286k as at 23 July (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-23-july-2021), and that week increased cases by 33700, we see it will take about 3 weeks for the number to break 350k. This takes us to 13 August. And "before 12 August 2021" will not count the week anyway, so it seems we will run out of time just.  So I amend my forecast from 5% between 29 July and 11 August and 95% Not before 12 August to 35%, 65%, because it's going to the wire. But my forecast seems to be much better than the majority below even after the move. This demonstrates the value of trying to avoid relying on just one big idea. In this case, I had two (confirmed case != confirmed delta case and the vaccine effect), one seems to be pretty much bang on, and the other was overestimated. The result is one saves the other so my original and new forecasts remain in play despite a mistake.

286,765 is the total number of confirmed (sequencing) and probable (genotyping) cases till July 21; last  week the number of cases increased by ~34K.
In any case, it won't exceed 350K next week.  I should have assigned probability estimates to different periods, rather than trying to get it right.
Delta 286,765 as per data up to 21 July. , Up 33,716 from prior week.

The new data for the week ending Jul 21 is in. The total is at 286.7K, with 33.7K cases added in the previous week, continuing the trend of slow down that started in the previous week (36.8K the week ending Jul 14, 54.2K the week ending Jul 7). To get to above 350K by Jul 28, the next week will need to be above 63.3K cases, almost double the rate of the previous 2 weeks. That's unlikely, especially given the daily numbers we see here: https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/cases. So changing my previous forecast. 
In retrospect, the mistake I've made in the previous forecast was that I have ignored the last week as a "fluke", while it was the best data point I had.
Still leaving a possibility that something will happen this week but I doubt it more than my probability would suggest

Almost no chance it'll be above 350k at next reporting unless the mega lab goes nuts this week. 90% chance it'll be above 350k on the Aug 4th reporting, 100% it'll be there by the 11th.

Let see:
 - total delta variant cases according to the source to the 23rd of July: 286,765 (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-23-july-2021).
 - so another 63,235 cases gets us to 350K all together.
 - in reality: almost all cases in the UK this wave are believed to be delta variant, so we're way past 350K already.
 - it looks like the source might only be reporting around 26% of true cases (comparing to a range of data from https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/cases).
 - we're getting about 47K new cases per day (https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/details/cases again), 26% x 47K = 12.22K, and at that rate we'll hit 350K around the the 29th of July.
 - in practice I believe that 26% figure is falling; it's more like 11% for the most recent week of data, 11% x 47K = 5.17K / day, hitting 350K around the 5th of August.
 - it's unclear if cases are still rising exponential (doubling every 14 days) or whether they're levelling off, but I don't expect them to fall sharply (because no measures have been put into place that would cause a sharp change).

The new mega-lab mentioned on previous comment is only operating at ~1/12th capacity due to delays, shortages and other issues:
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2021/07/18/exclusive-covid-testing-mega-lab-operating-less-10-per-cent/
And we still don't know how much this affects the ultra-high-throughput ePCR testing kit, which is capable of processing 150,000/day. The lab will also carry out genotype assay testing, which is more crucial to the outcome of this question, but there is no clear guidance when this will start.
From the most recent SAGE report (12th July) Point 10: 'High prevalence also presents a challenge to testing, contact tracing and sequencing. If PCR testing and genomic sequencing capacity are overwhelmed, it may not be possible to rapidly identify a new variant'. 
So capacity is very much an issue, and near or at the current limit:
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sage-93-minutes-coronavirus-covid-19-response-7-july-2021/sage-93-minutes-coronavirus-covid-19-response-7-july-2021
PHE (Public Health England) already provides sequencing expertise and support to other countries (through NVAP) but perhaps more significantly has sequenced samples from at least four other countries, and is expecting demand to increase: 
https://www.gov.uk/government/news/phe-to-provide-genomic-sequencing-support-to-partners-across-the-world
Again this demand will limit available capacity each week and may cap increases (barring any mega-lab factor). 
So summing up: It's still a tussle between immediate demands and available capacity, and while a partially operational mega-lab would have the throughput to quickly increase capacity I suspect they are still weeks from operating efficiently. I'm hedging towards 40K results this week and 40-50K next week.

There are 253K cases up to Jul 14, with 36.8K new cases added in the previous week and 54.2K cases in the week before. Assuming that the 36.8K cases is a temporary "fluke" and the rate will actually grow to at least 48.5K / week in the next 2 weeks until July 28, this will get us to above 350K cases by July 28. Assuming a 20% chance that the rate will slow down to below 48.5K per week.

Responding to the comment from jflom, I used https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-16-july-2021 as the source instead, where a total of 253,049 cases of Delta were sequenced in the UK, with 36,800 new Delta cases this week. It gives a rough estimate of 14% increase every week. With this crude rate, Delta cases would exceed 350,000 by 4 August. However, there are many people infected with COVID or fully vaccinated in UK already, and reinfection is rare according to https://www.healthline.com/health-news/can-you-get-delta-variant-if-you-already-had-covid-19#Reinfection-remains-rare. Therefore, the rate would well be smaller than the crude estimate, and it would be harder to spread when more people are infected, since the uninfected ones would be the once-infected or vaccinated individuals. Using a decreasing rate of 12%, 10%, 8%, 6%, the cases would surpass 350,000 by 11 August.
I used a linear model since it seems like thats how the numbers have been evolving in the last 6 updates

Looking at the statistics over the last two weeks: 253,049 total cases as of Jul 14
36,800 new cases in the week of Jul 14
54,268 new cases in the week of Jul 7 Based on the data over the last two weeks (rate of cases, along with change in rate; i.e. the number of cases/week is decreasing, indicating that the rise in Delta variant cases is no longer exponential), using a simple curve fitting model gives a ballpark of ~3-4 weeks from July 14 (date of the report) for the spread of another 97k cases (the UK population is ~66 million, so it isn't a limiting factor). That puts the best estimate date at around the week of Aug 5 - Aug 11. Since this is near the back end of the "Between 29 July and 11 August 2021" range, I'm giving a little more weight to the "Not before 12 August 2021" range and a little less to the earlier "Between 15 July and 28 July 2021" range. Finally, since it is July 19 now as of the time of my posting, "On or before 14 July 2021" is clearly 0% probability. Source: https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/britain-reports-36800-new-cases-delta-variant-latest-week-2021-07-16/

Therefore, the rate would well be smaller than the crude estimate, and it would be harder to spread when more people are infected, since the uninfected ones would be the once-infected or vaccinated individuals. We can't know the answer. But in the lab, whatever can go wrong generally does, so I'm going to weight the later bin a bit higher at this point. So I don't expect help from them over the rest of the month. And once again, I have learned my lesson the hard way not to remove weight from bins because they "shouldn't" happen. The delta variant is the fastest-growing COVID variant in the UK at the moment, and in the 7-day periods ending 30 June and 23 June recorded a nearly 50% week-to-week increase in confirmed cases. If case numbers continue to grow at the same rate, the UK will be just shy of 350,000 delta variant cases by 14 July. Recent data suggests that the UK is entering another COVID peak, so it is likely that cases will be able to sustain this exponential growth for the near future. The delta variant has taken hold in the UK over the past few weeks despite robust vaccination efforts, so even as inoculation rates rise, the virus is unlikely to be slowed dramatically. Moreover, the UK just lifted almost all restrictions, and a return to lockdown seems unlikely given the present present political climate.

Despite continued growth in number of cases, (161k with a 50k rise from prior week as of June 30th), UK is still set to lift the final pandemic restrictions (https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-delta-variant-surges-in-u-k-boris-johnson-lifts-most-covid-19-curbs-11625506392). At the current rate, it seems that it will take about 3-4 weeks since June 30th to hit 350k cases; with more reopening, the less effectiveness of the vaccines as announced today, and the exponential nature of infectious diseases, I am revising my forecast to very low after July 28th. I am choosing to allocate more probability for between 15th and 28th to account for the fact that July 14th is only a week away, and the current growth rate doesn't seem fast enough to hit 350k by then. However, the easing of restrictions is likely going to accelerate the spread, so before July 14th is still higher than after July 28th.
Editing probabilities in response to comment

Looking first at base rates in the UK, of the original strain: 
From 48K to 350K took 5 months
From 350K to 700K took 1 month
From 284K to 634K took 2.3 months
Alpha variant statistics:
The UK currently has 265K cases of the Alpha variant, which was first detected in fall 2020. It was 50% more transmissible than the original, and accounted for 90% of the UK cases at one point. 
Delta variant statistics: 
It is 50% more contagious than Alpha, and has rapidly overcome Alpha and now accounts for 90% of the UK cases.
Compared to the original, Delta spreads approximately 2.25 faster, and 1.5 faster than Alpha. My estimate for the amount of time is therefore approximately 2.2 months as of June 9, which makes it around August 18. Note that Alpha never exceeded 350K, primarily because it was overtaken by another variant. So, there is also a chance that a new variant arrives that makes the Delta variant never exceed 350K. The variants of concern (Alpha Beta Gamma and Delta), all emerged late 2020. There is a rising variant of interest (Lambda) that may have increased transmissibility, but as potential resistance to the vaccine. For me, this means the probability for a new variant is quite low, and more probable that Lambda will overtake Delta, which is still a low probability (~2%) before August 11.  Looking at vaccination rates, currently 50% of the population is fully vaccinated, and this number is still increasing. The cases from Alpha / the original were during a time when, while there were less people out, there were also much fewer vaccinations. Overall, I think these cancel each other out, with perhaps the current vaccinations making the Delta variant spread slightly slower than the original or Alpha variant.  Assuming a somewhat normal distribution for the time until the Delta variant exceeds 350K cases in the UK, this puts my probability that it happens before August 12 at slightly greater than 50%, with decreasing probabilities going earlier into the year. We can model the number of daily new Delta cases as exponential to approximate roughly how a virus spreads, by c*r^t where c is an initial constant, r is growth rate, and t is time. This exponential model is a common model for infections. Using https://www.bbc.com/news/health-57489740 we know up to June 16 there were almost 76,000 COVID cases caused by the Delta variant in the UK, and that the number of new COVID cases caused by the Delta variant is between around 90% and 100% of new COVID cases from around June 13 assuming trends continue (see graph in link). This is a reasonable assumption as the Delta variant continues to threaten the UK and be a major threat, and is corroborated as per this article which says the Delta variant accounts for 99% of COVID tests in the UK: https://www.usnews.com/news/health-news/articles/2021-06-18/delta-variant-makes-up-nearly-all-new-uk-coronavirus-cases. The number of new COVID cases on June 16 was 8808 and the number of new COVID cases on July 5 is 27100. Assuming Delta variant accounts for the lower bound of 90% of COVID cases for both values we can solve to get c=7927.2, r=1.0609. Assuming Delta variant accounts for the upper bound of 100% of COVID cases for both values we can solve to get c=8808, r=1.0609 (note r is the same; this makes sense based on how one solves the equation). We want to find T so that the integral from 0 to T of cr^t dt is at least 350,000-76,000 = 274,000. We can evaluate this integral to be c/ln r (r^T-1). If we take c=7927.2 we get T >= 18.83 and if we take C=8808 we get T >= 17.65. These dates correspond to July 6th and July 4th respectively, that is today. This may see like a harsh prediction but it makes sense considering the 7 day average of COVID cases in the UK since July 5th is around 25k and the 7 day average of COVID cases from the week before is around 16k. Assuming approximately 90% of COVID cases in the UK have been caused by Delta since this comes out to 41k*7*.9 which is around 258k COVID cases since June 21 caused by Delta, matching the earlier predictions. So I will in fact given the probability of this occurring before or on July 14 which is in over 1 week an 85% chance and the following event a 15% chance, giving a 0% chance for the last two events.

This question doesn't ask when there will be at least 350k confirmed cases in the UK that are due to Delta, which one could approximate by counting case numbers and multiplying by the percentage estimated to be due to Delta, and adding these over time. This question asks when the UK will have *genetically characterized* (by genotyping or sequencing) at least 350K cases as Delta. These are very different questions. Cases are growing much faster than they can be characterized. Laboratory characterization of strains appears to be a big bottleneck. The number of characterized Delta samples is going up like a 2nd degree polynomial, more slowly than cases. From June 16 to 23, there were 0.07M confirmed cases in the UK, nearly all of which were due to Delta, but only ~38k cases (all strains) were characterized. The percentage characterized seems to be falling. With a 2nd degree polynomial fit, my projection is that 350k cases will be characterized and recorded on the relevant website within the data in the week ending Aug. 4. This would require ~250k more samples between now and Aug. 4 to be characterized, or an average of ~42k/week. I think this is feasible, given that they're already processing ~38k/week. It shouldn't be too hard to ramp up characterization by 10% to 20%. Given that they haven't even been able to characterize 40k samples per week, the chance that 250k more samples will be characterized as Delta over the next 3 weeks is zero (i.e., the probability of bin 1 is zero). And unless they seriously ramp up testing, there's no way they'll characterize 350k samples as Delta by the end of July (bin 2). They're in the process of testing their new genotyping assay in national reference laboratories; if all goes well with that, it's conceivable that that genotyping capability could be expanded to other labs across the UK. So I'll give a little weight to bin 2. But I'll also give a little weight to bin 4. For further information, see the comments and discussion here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1296120 Given that many people seem to be answering a different question (when there will be at least 350k confirmed cases in the UK that are likely due to Delta), I think the median Brier score on this is going to be pretty big.

This question isn't about how fast Delta will spread; the limiting factor is going to be sequencing and genotyping capabilities. The UK has ~9k new cases per day, 99% of which are the Delta variant. In the week ending June 16, in the ballpark of 47k Delta cases were confirmed, yet only 33.6k (~71%) were added to the figure being forecasted. In the previous week, in the ballpark of 41k Delta cases were added, but only 29.9k (~73%) were added to the forecast figure. So, as long as ~72% of all Delta samples continue to be sequenced and genotyped, if cases continue to grow as they have so far, then we'll see 350k by the end of July. However, if more restrictions are put in place, then it won't.

Looking at COVID cases last year in the UK (when COVID was just introduced, similar to now, when Delta has just been introduced), the peak was about 5300 cases a day. This lasted for about two months. We can use this as a baserate for how fast infections will spread when a new variant is introduced in the UK.  The differences this summer from last year is that there is a vaccine, although it is less effective against Delta (33% efficacy in-between doses, src below) than against the original COVID. This presence of a vaccine leads me to expect a decrease from the baserate. However, on the other hand, lockdowns this year are less stringent than last year, leading me to expect an increase from the baserate. These factors sort of cancel out, and it's hard to quantify how much each factor will contribute to the final results; thus, I will just use last year's rate of about 5000 cases a day as a baserate. Okay, lets start with a superficial look at the data. 
https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/covid-19-variants-genomically-confirmed-case-numbers/variants-distribution-of-case-data-11-june-2021 First of all, if we sum up all the total cases of all known variants, we get only about 300k. The total national cases seem to be about 4.63 million, but confirming Covid 19 vs confirming a specific variant is very different and the question relies solely on the above link.  So what we are really asking is whether there will be more cases of delta variant than the entirety of the rest of the pandemic.  Looking also only at the data, we got about 30k more cases between 2 June and today (21 June), so about 70k in total. At this rate, it will take (350-70) = 4 periods of 19 days = 76 days to reach 350k, which is about 2.5 months. This takes us to September. But that is the superficial look. Moving into the details, at the moment, the UK is heavily vaccinated with all those over 21 or so now being offered a first vaccine and with most over 40 being offered a second vaccine. And the evidence shows transmission of the delta variant is heavily reduced by the vaccine. In fact, we in the UK are very close to "herd immunity" now and even the delta variant cases are now being pushed into retreat. Further, areas with outbreaks of delta are being prioritised and this has succeeded in ending the local outbreak and virtually every single case of the delta variant appears to be happening in the increasingly small unvaccinated population.  On the other hand, infections are not linear, they are exponential so can grow very quickly. But this works both ways. They can shrink quickly too.  The evidence therefore shows the delta variant is on the wane and cannot sustain itself very long.  I therefore conclude a small chance (5%) of between 29 July and 11 August but a very high chance of never and certainly not before 12 August.  Why 5%? 1% chance of being spectacularly wrong and 4% because of the non-linearities of the exponential distribution. I observe my forecast is totally out of kilter with the rest of the community. But my forecast is my forecast and crowd views alone are not generally a direct input in my forecasts, particularly given the abundance of pure fear going around about the delta variant. So rather than change my forecast with the crowd, I say "bring it on".
